text:
RAMSEY KHABBAZ: I'm
Ramsey Khabbaz, an editor
at Harvard Business Review.

And today, I'm
going to be trying
to understand, what are NFTs?

I've been seeing this new
acronym in the news a lot
lately.
NFTs seem to be everywhere.
Everyone's talking about them.

But I'm having a really
hard time understanding.
What are these things?
How do they work?
What's the point of them?

And what are the
implications on business?

So in order to unpack
it, I called up
my colleague, Tom Stackpole.

He is a senior editor of
technology here at HBR.
Tom, NFTs, explain them to me.
THOMAS STACKPOLE: Absolutely.
They are kind of confusing.

NFT stands for
non-fungible token.

And basically, what this means
is it's a digital object,
and it's one of a kind.

RAMSEY KHABBAZ: Can you
explain this term non-fungible?

Because aside from just
being a fun word to say,

I feel like it's a key
term in this acronym.
THOMAS STACKPOLE: Right.
Totally.

So yeah, fungibility
is the key here, right?

Fungibility means you
can exchange something

for something that's
exactly the same.

Dollars are fungible,
but the Mona Lisa is not.
There's one Mona Lisa.

You can look at replicas
or posters of it,

but there's really
just one of them.

RAMSEY KHABBAZ: Could
you explain to me

how NFTs relate to two
other key tech buzzwords--
Bitcoin and blockchain?

What's the relationship
between those three terms?

THOMAS STACKPOLE: So
NFTs and Bitcoin--
or cryptocurrency in general--
are built on blockchain.

Blockchain is a
term we hear a lot,

but it basically
means a technology
that uses a distributed ledger.

So the trick about
a distributed ledger

is it basically means the
same information is stored
in a bunch of different places.

With cryptocurrency, it's a way
to verify that digital money is

real, that it's worth something,
And it's not just like--

I don't know-- a PDF
that I made that says,
I have this much money.

With NFTs, basically you
get a stamp that says,

I bought this gift, and
this is the original gift.
This is the real one.

RAMSEY KHABBAZ: So
in real world terms,

blockchain is basically
just creating a certificate

of authenticity
that you would get

with any expensive piece of
art or expensive collectible.
THOMAS STACKPOLE: Yeah, exactly.

And the way that it
works is that it's

stored in a bunch of different
places at the same time.

So it's like, you can't
forge it because it's on all
of these other computers.

RAMSEY KHABBAZ: Can you give
us some examples of where NFTs
are popping up in real life?

THOMAS STACKPOLE: I mean,
basically, the reason

they're in the news
is because people
are making a ton of money.

A piece of art by
an artist named

Beeple was sold at
Christie's for $69 million.

Also, artists like Grimes have
been making NFT pieces of art

that they've sold
for bunches of money.

The NBA is getting
in on the game.

They've been making these
trading-card-style NFTs called
Moments.
So you're an NBA guy, right?
You collect cards.

RAMSEY KHABBAZ: I
used to collect cards.

But I don't know if I'm going
to be getting into the Top Shot
craze.
[CHUCKLES]

THOMAS STACKPOLE: So
basically, with Top Shot,

it's basically clips that
you can find on YouTube,

but they're an authenticated
part of a series.

So yeah, basically, there's
this new collecting craze,

and people are
burning through cash.

RAMSEY KHABBAZ: Are the people
spending on NFTs right now

and putting their
money in there?

Do you think that
they're doing so

because they see
a real collectible
value in these things?

Or do you think it's a
more cynical money move,

and they're just going to
plan on flipping and riding
this wave?

THOMAS STACKPOLE: I
think a lot of people
are asking that question.

And so if you think
about collecting

and why people
collect, they collect
for all kinds of reasons.

And on some level, most of
them are irrational, right?

Beanie Babies are a
couple dollars of--

maybe, not even that--
but a little bit

of fabric and stuffing, and
those were worth a ton of money
at some point.

A Michael Jordan rookie
card is just paper and ink,

but some people are
investing in it.

Some people, maybe, are
just super into basketball,

and like the history,
and like the fact

that they own an object
that other people can't
get their hands on.

I think the thing that's
driving this is scarcity.

So if you think about the
digital economy, up until now,

scarcity has been
really hard to create.
It's like, I make a funny GIF.

Give me some credit
for trying to do that.

But let's say I made
a GIF that's great,
and it went viral.

With NFTs, all of a sudden it's
like, you can create scarcity
on the internet.

You know the flying Pop Tart
cat with the rainbow, Nyan Cat?

RAMSEY KHABBAZ: Nyan-- yeah,
I don't know how to say it.
[CHUCKLES]

THOMAS STACKPOLE: I think
that's how you say it.
I don't know either.
I hope it's how you say it.

But now, you can be like,
oh yeah, I own Nyan Cat.

Everyone can see it,
but you're the guy
who owns the Nyan Cat GIF.

RAMSEY KHABBAZ: What
happens if people

stop believing that
the scarcity actually
makes these things valuable?
THOMAS STACKPOLE: Yeah.

I mean, that is
a great question.

I think if people
stop believing in it,

then the price of these things
is going to come crashing down.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

RAMSEY KHABBAZ: What are the
implications of all of this?

Because it seems like
the applications of NFTs
is kind of endless.

As you're explaining
this to me, I'm

imagining so many
different possibilities
for this technology.

So what do you predict is going
to be the biggest story to come
out of this craze?

THOMAS STACKPOLE:
You know, I think

that it shows a couple
of things, one of which

is it's one of these use
cases for how you use

a blockchain that we've been
hearing about for a long time,

that blockchain can do
all of these things.

And we're finally
seeing a new example
other than cryptocurrency.

This is an interesting case
of how you create value

and how you can really
lean into the distributed

nature of this technology, that
you don't need gatekeepers.
You can make art.

You can find a way
to sell it yourself,

which people have
obviously been able to do.

But it's sort of
upping the scale.

I also think that
NFTs, possibly,

do have more mundane
business uses.

And so that's something that I'm
curious to see if people look

at this and they're like, well,
if this works for a flying

rainbow cat, then
maybe I can find a way

to use this for
contracts or securities.

There are probably more
mundane business uses for this.

RAMSEY KHABBAZ: So
just moving forward,

do you think that this
is a story that I,

as someone who isn't
really a tech specialist,
should I keep an eye on this?

Or is this one of those things
that I could just kind of

scroll past the next time
it comes up on my news feed.

THOMAS STACKPOLE: To
me, NFT is kind of a--

this whole hype thing
is a fun thing to watch.

It's people engaging
with blockchain

in a new way, outside
of cryptocurrency.

And so, I think it is
bringing this a little bit
closer to the mainstream.

And it's helping
people understand

the multitude of uses that
blockchain really has.

But don't cash out
your retirement

to fund your NFT art
collection quite yet.

RAMSEY KHABBAZ:
Well, all my money

is tied up in Kevin Durant
rookie cards anyway, so--

THOMAS STACKPOLE:
[CHUCKLES] A safer bet.
Stick with Kevin Durant.
[CHUCKLES]

RAMSEY KHABBAZ: Yeah, I'm
sticking with paper for now.

Tom, thank you so much
for chatting with me.
This has been really helpful.

THOMAS STACKPOLE:
Thanks, Ramsey.
I'll see you on [INAUDIBLE].
[MUSIC PLAYING]
